snippet.title: Punters spent $14.83m at Dingley pokies venue last year
snippet.content: PUNTERS spent $83.02 million at pokies machines across Kingston last year, placing the region among the worst 10 areas in the state. It's expenditure the council says is far too high, despite a fall of $450,000 from the previous financial year. "Council is concerned about the high density of electronic gaming machines in Kingston, the large amounts of money lost and the negative impacts on the community resulting from problem gambling," community sustainability general manager Mauro Bolin said. "It's incredibly concerning Kingston has again been listed in the state's worst areas for pokies losses." Of the 16 pokies venues in Kingston, eight are hotels and eight are clubs, with Dingley International causing the most damage in 2016-17 when punters spending $14.83 million. The hotel has 90 pokies that drained an average $164,777 from each punter - almost double the average loss incurred across the state's 502 venues. Alliance for Gambling Reform director Tim Costello said real reform would only occur from an "all hands on deck" approach and congratulated Kingston Council for joining the Alliance. "With Kingston and Knox joining Monash and Greater Dandenong, the Alliance now has a formidable group of councils in Melbourne's southeast, which is important because this has been a region of great poker machine harm," Mr Costello said. Kingston council wants to prevent new machines and venues from being located in areas of high social disadvantage, placed used by children or young people or near public housing estates, mental health clinics, and major activity hubs. The State Government is now working on legislation that would regulate the industry over the next 25 years.
